bo-resolutions

Dec 27, 2019

Mahowald’s got this really interesting paper, called -resolutions, where he describes the -based Adams spectral sequence, and uses it to prove the telescope conjecture at height . He derives differentials in this spectral sequence by comparison to the -based Adams spectral sequence, where (see Section 2 here — that paper contains the details of some of what I did this summer!). Mark and a bunch of other people have a paper on -resolutions, and I’m working on a project that uses Mahowald’s techniques to obtain differentials in the -ASS via this spectrum that I study in my Ando-Hopkins-Rezk surjectivity paper. Before I talk about that, I want to discuss Mahowald’s paper. It’s incredibly dense, and consequently is virtually impenetrable by a mortal like me. I’d like to record what (little) I understand of it.

There are a few results we’ll take for granted/not discuss here; see also Section 2 of BBBCX, whose notation we’ll be following. One of these results is the following: let denote the th integral Brown-Gitler spectrum. Then

(Later, I’ll talk about how this relates to the splitting of the Tate spectrum .) One can also determine the homotopy type of : Mahowald shows that

where is the sum of digits in the base -expansion of , and denotes the th Adams cover of (so forms a minimal Adams resolution of ).

The -Adams spectral sequence runs

Iterating the identification of splits up the -term, and in particular, the mod Eilenbeg-Maclane summands give rise to a subcomplex of the -page. The BBBCX paper calls this the “evil” complex. The quotient of the -page by gives rise to the “good” complex .

Let’s get to the differentials. Write for an element . Generators of are of the form , where . Then (see Theorem 3.7 here):

and everything else is determined by -linearity.

How is this differential determined? Well, the first sum simply comes from the expression for the right unit on in . The other part of this differential is determined by comparison to the -based ASS. Recall that is the -quotient of by . There is an -map (again, see my paper, or practically any of Mahowald’s papers from the ’70s), which gives a map from the -based ASS to the -based ASS. The idea is to transport differentials in the -based ASS to the -based ASS. For this, we need to first understand differentials in the -based ASS — as it turns out, we’ll only need to think about -differentials for our applications to the -ASS.

The -based resolution of the sphere goes

The Thom isomorphism gives an equivalence , and the James splitting further gives an equivalence . This is very closely related to the splitting of : there is a diagram

which commutes up to elements of Adams filtration (not sure I fully understand why yet).

The differential in the -ASS is determined by the map , which in turn is determined by the maps coming from the James splitting. Since the map is obtained by Thomification of the map

it sends

(Everything’s in mod homology.) Consequently, iterating this gives the effect of the map in homology. This tells us the effect of on an ASS representative of an element of .

In fact, , where is sent to (see Proposition 2.6 here). In fact, one can write . Write

then is primitive in , and detects in the ANSS of the sphere. The calculation above of the coproduct in the -Hopf algebroid for amounts to the expression for on the top of page 9 here. Our entire argument above is actually just the BBBCX argument, rephrased in terms of .

(Note that the above formula for tells us that the map is of degree on the cell in dimension . For instance, this implies that the map is of degree in dimension . Since there is a commutative (up to elements of Adams filtration ) diagram

we find that the map is of degree in dimension . Consequently, this map increases Adams filtration by in dimension . This is how you get what’s claimed right before Proposition 5.15 in Mahowald’s paper.)

Once you’ve got these differentials, you need to calculate the cohomology of the good complex. This turns out to be challenging, but doable (Corollary 4.9 of BBBCX). I don’t want to get into its calculation now. Importantly, there is a slope vanishing line in the -ASS: check out the BBBCX paper; they explain it better than I can (in part because I don’t fully grok the proof, which is highly calculational). One can use this to argue directly that the cycles in in -filtration and are permanent cycles; see Section 8.4 of this awesome document.
